utterances.sentences: There are things that women do that are bad also, and if we want to talk about toxic masculinity, maybe we should talk about toxic femininity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It exists.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And toxic feminism. And the fact that taking men out of being masculine isn't going to make their behavior better. It's only going to take things that the country has built itself upon out of the picture and make the behavior worse. Men need men to show them how to be good people, to have morals and values. That doesn't mean they have to stop acting like men.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, there could have been a positive message, Juan. But in this case, it was negative. The assumption being that men don't have sisters, don't have mothers, don't have daughters, granddaughters. That we actually love women. In this case, we're just awful people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I really think you're off on this one. And I'm a guy, but when I must say that, when it comes to any talk about racism, the Steve Kings of the world; when it comes to misogyny; when it comes to bullying, you guys react like, "Oh, somebody is attacking the Republican Party." I'm like, "What?"

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Who said that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's B.S. That is pure B.S. That had nothing to do with racism or Steve King.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You -- you -- you know what? You know what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are so wrong. Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And by the way --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, that is so pathetic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, you are --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you are out -- totally out of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You're embarrassing yourself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- keeping with a company that's here to make money, just like we talked about Nike.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I agree. Just make money. Just to make money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Please, just give me a second. So what you have here is a company that I don't doubt tested this and found that men, in fact, are moving away from "all men have to be stoic."

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Then we're doomed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: "All men have to project" --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: America is over.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- "that they are extremely confident."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Stoicism is growing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? You have a situation here where high rates of violence, high rates of depression, high rates of spousal abuse, men.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Why is that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Men understand that there is a change taking place. And I think it's also the case that, as we see shifts in demographics about Hispanic men, black men, Asian men, that there's more and more open to the idea that, you know, it's a different definition of what it means to be "big daddy" in this country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That made -- that made no sense at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Gillette is at the cutting edge of saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Cutting edge, good one, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- hey, there's a movement. Yes, I agree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That made no sense. OK. How has "The Five" aged in the past ten years? We'll show you as we join the latest social media trend, next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: A new viral challenge has hit social media. It's called the ten- year challenge, where users post side-by-side photos of themselves from 2009 and 2019 to show how much they've aged. Here are a few celebrity examples. There's actress Reese Witherspoon. Television host and radio star Ryan Seacrest. And actor and comedian Kevin hard. And now "The Five" is joining in on the fun. I wanted to do this --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Celebrities.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- with my Instagram pictures, so I'm really glad that we're doing this. Juan, show us the past ten years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, there you go. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Explain the context of these photos.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think the -- I think the big difference there would be the hair. I think my hairline is a little weaker now. And I think that I have more gray before I started putting some color in there. But I think the other thing -- the other thing that strikes me about this is the question of wrinkles. And it doesn't look like I've done too badly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, you're pretty good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like the gray better.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Pretty good on that front.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'd get rid of that jacket, though.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You like -- you don't like the brown jacket?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like the gray.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It was ten years ago, bro. Ten years.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It was in style then. OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think it was.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what this picture looks like, but let's roll it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I remember that. That's in Ventura Beach, California, I think. Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Was that a "Watters' World" assignment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was a "Watters' World," yes, of course. Wow. I think I -- that hair was not good back then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You have good hair now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think my hair is better now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ten years from now, you'll feel differently.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It looks like someone's goosing you in that current picture.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It does. Looks like it. OK, Greg. Your turn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ooh, jeez.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oooh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow. I look -- my teeth are darker. Could that be the wine?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think it's just the light. I think it's the lighting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think it's the wine. Definitely losing some hair. That's for sure. And it seems that I've gotten shorter, which technically, I think every decade -- every decade, you do get shorter.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's only shorter because your hair looks shorter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My teeth. I've got to get my teeth whitened. Jeez Louise.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Dana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dana has a dentist for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I -- yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Whoa, that's a different picture.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That is, like, a totally different -- I was like -- ten years ago I could barely walk by the end of -- that was my last press briefing, which was about a year ago this week --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are you sure that's you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Ten years ago this week.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: That's Dana at the White House in the Brady Briefing Room.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I have some time now to do some hair and makeup.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Aww.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK, here's mine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I did not have hair and makeup.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Here I am on the left at my college news station, doing the weekly political statement. And there I am on "The Five" yesterday. So I think that I've improved quite a bit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Jeez, wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I would say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's a little humbling, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Look, I'm in a T-shirt like Steve Hilton on the left. My hair is green from the green screen. We didn't have much editing going on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Weren't you playing sports at that time?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Not in college. In high school, but not in college. So I feel like I've come a long way. Ten years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That was pretty fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't like mine. I think the producers are mad at me for some reason.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It was a pretty good picture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not a good picture, guys. Let's work on that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You went on TV that way. You went on TV that way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I didn't have hair and makeup. I was the only one with no hair and makeup.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You could have sent in your own photos.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't have pictures of myself from ten years ago. What am I, a narcissist?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Some of us decided to -- did you see my hair? My hair was green. At least your hair wasn't green.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It looked like you at least tried to do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I did not try.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: At least you looked like the same person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was windswept.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You do look like the same person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was a look, wasn't it? The little bob?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This difference doesn't matter until you're way older, like between 70 and 80. Then the difference really tells.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Or like a 20-year difference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But what would your advice be, Greg, to those who are getting older?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It gets better.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Are you sure?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Way better. Trust me. Oh, man. It's so much more fun. You stop caring, you do whatever you want.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you become an angry old coot. That's it. I've got to tell you, so this year, 2019, I'm going to be 65. And so I'm thinking, boy, this -- is there going to be, like, an immediate drop off?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Are you going to retire, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Only -- only if you come with me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I want that -- I want that hairstyle.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right, well, Juan is not retiring, just so everybody knows. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Time for --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Journey to a Driver's License!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Journey to a Driver's License!" Yes, I'm going to take you along this journey, America. So I went to the DMV, and I got a 20 out of 20 on my written exam.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But I did drop my Social Security card on the floor, and I was in an ensuing panic, running around screaming and yelling. Having said that, and I thought everything was great. And then I was told as I was leaving, that, "And you will have to sign up for a five-hour" -- I have to sign up for a five-hour driver's course.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I have to take a driver's course. So if there's anybody in New York who does a drivers course, give me a call. Because I'm going to - - I don't even know how to do it! I don't know, where am I going to go?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What does that mean? Like a racecar course?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They have schools. I don't want to go to a school. There's got to be some kind of independent dude with a pickup truck.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Why are you getting a driver's license, by the way?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because I -- I've got to start driving again.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's been a long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wants some independence.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I need some independence.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And you've got to have an escape from the city.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Going to take five hours to get there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I went to the DMV this morning, and I'm getting a colonoscopy tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: This is a banner week for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what the best part about you going to the DMV? You didn't do "Animals Are Great" tonight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Very good. All right. I'm going to go next. A new study gives me so much hope. It's about Americans' reading habits. Jesse, pay attention.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The study found that 86 percent of those surveyed feel they make a conscious effort to read in some way every day. And get this: The biggest number, between 25- and 34-year-olds. They read almost three hours a day. So this is, like, a really good thing. Right? People thought that books were going to go away, people aren't going to read anymore. But they are, and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What are they reading?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm going to tell you what I've read recently. Three books I've read recently.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I mean, what are they saying they're reading? They're reading on the Internet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Social media, but they're also reading proper books.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's not reading.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Proper books. Finishing a book. I mean, 67 percent of respondents say they feel accomplished after reading a book. So maybe they're buying your books. Let's be celebratory. Those are some books I've read. "Bridge of Clay" by Markus Zusak. I loved it. "My Absolute Darling," oh, my gosh. That one was really hard. And "Stories I Tell My Friends" by Rob Lowe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: "Art of the Deal" was pretty good. Read that one?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Everybody has. Everybody has read that book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Page turner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, wait. It's Juan's turn.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. So you know, the little kid in me loves to watch things go boom. And so take a look at what happened to New York's Tappan Zee Bridge today.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow. Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, the eastern section of the bridge tumbled into the Hudson River. Once the waves of black smoke dispersed in the cold winter air, the bridge could be seen half-submerged in the chilly waters. Hundreds of New Yorkers braved the cold to witness the 63-year-old bridge's demolition. They chanted, "Blow it up! Blow it up!" The bridge is being replaced by a new bridge named for Mario Cuomo, the father of New York's current governor. So --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who built that bridge, Juan!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What did you say?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who built that bridge, do you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Maybe some men did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Watching this blow up, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, women can't build bridges. That's impossible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, go next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't drive over that bridge, by the way. It's blown up. You're going to get hurt. All right. The Jets brought in the head coach for Miami. This guy, Gase, he had a press conference. Look at this guy. This is -- this is the new head coach of your New York Jets, everybody.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Did he do this on purpose? Did he do this on purpose? Come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know we've got some Jets fans here in the building. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like, what is he doing, seriously?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This will be -- this guy will be leading your team into the playoffs. I'm just kidding.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Was this on purpose so he never has to do another press conference?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No one knows. No one knows why he's doing this or what he's doing. But that's the head coach of the Jets.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: "Maybe if I do this, they'll never come after me (PH)."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Also, "Watters' World" has its own Instagram page now. So there you go. Go leave me all your nasty comments in one place, and I'll read them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Check out this video of a little baby girl. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (singing): Baby sister.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: (laughs)

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. So 11th month-year-old Scarlett was born three months early and suffered a serious infection, which led to her having hearing loss. And she just heard her big sister, Haley's voice for the first time after she got her hearing aid.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Aww, that's cute.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So science is great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And a really heartwarming story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's great for that family. All right, set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of The Five. Why would you? It's amazing. But now, "Special Report" is up next.
