utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I am Dana Perino along with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is THE FIVE. Fox News alert. You are looking live at the hearing of President Trump's attorney general nominee, William Barr. Fielding questions from lawmakers on Capitol Hill, and if anything major happens in the hearing, we will take you back in there live. Barr spending most of the day attempting to reassure Democrats they have no reason to be concerned about the Mueller investigation and a previous memo he wrote about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL NOMINEE
utterances.utterance: I believe it's vitally important that the special counsel be allowed to complete his investigation. I believe it is in the best interest of everyone, the president, Congress, and the American people, that this matter be resolved by allowing the special counsel to complete his work. I wrote the memo as a former attorney general who has often weighed in on legal issues of public importance and I distributed broadly so that other lawyers would have the benefit of my views. My memo was narrow, explaining my thinking on a specific obstruction of justice theory under a single statute that I thought, based on media reports, the special counsel might be considering.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But despite clearly laying out his stance, Democrats tried to hammer him on the same issue.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It look like a job application?

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.utterance: That's ludicrous. If I wanted the job and was going after the job, there are many more direct ways of me bringing myself to the president's attention than writing in the 18-page legal memorandum.

utterances.speaker: SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL, D-CONN.
utterances.utterance: Will you commit to this committee that you will not allow the president or his attorneys to edit or change the special counsel report before it is submitted to Congress or the public?

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.utterance: I've already said that I would not permit editing of my report.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the as we've seen in previous hearings, Democrats also pressed the nominee about whether he would be able to stand up to President Trump.

utterances.speaker: SEN. DICK DURBIN, D-ILL.
utterances.utterance: What would be your breaking point? When would you pick up and leave? When is your Jim Mattis moment when the president has asked you to do something that you think is inconsistent with your oath?

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to do anything that I think is wrong and I will not be bullied into doing anything I think is wrong by anybody, whether it be editorial boards or Congress or the president. I'm going to do what I think is right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then I want to just play for you this other sound that was caught off camera of Senator Dianne Feinstein. You want to listen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: And so you see this is a pretty easy road for him heading to confirmation?

utterances.speaker: SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I think so. We'll see.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. So I think, you know, she is reading the tea leaves. This looks like a confirmation that might just sail through.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I get all the interest in the investigation but it's amazing how the media and the Democrats are following the same script. Super obsessed with how this will impact Mueller. I mean, if an asteroid came and wiped out half the United States, the most important -- the lead at MSNBC and CNN will be, "How does this impact the Mueller probe?" There are 150 million people dead but we need to know more about the Mueller probe. And then the gist is like every question is how are you going to deal with Donald Trump? So it basically boils down to this, we hate Trump. You like Trump? We hate you too. So, he's not applying for A.G. He's applying to gain entrance into the Donald Trump hate club. And he's got to like -- he's to say all the right things. I believe there is a tree house out back for that with a secret knock.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There might be -- you have here, Jesse, a nominee who is -- he has already been the attorney general before and in fact, when the senators were not referring to him as Mr. Barr, they would have to say general because it was the title and you hold it for the rest of your life. And he is guy who is willing to come back. He was almost going into semi- retirement. He's willing to be a public servant. How do you think it went today?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I think it went really well and Juan would agree with me so he doesn't get to speak. I believe he handled all these senators deftly and this was not a Jeff Sessions situation where he is like oh, da-da-da, da-da-da. He was very smooth and he was very direct. And everything he said was based on law. When he was asked, you know, what would you base a recusal on? He said, the facts. And it stopped a few senators in their tracks. They want him, and I agree with Greg, they don't want a Trumper as A.G. They want a weak A.G. They want someone that's going to recuse at the slightest whiff of controversy and they want someone that is going to treat Mueller like a god. And I think he kind of straddled that pretty well. He said, if there is something that's going to happen, I will deal with it but I'm not going to abdicate my responsibility as A.G. I have an authority here and I'm going to be a strong attorney general. But he also had said in this memo that Comey deserved to be fired and Mueller going after an obstruction case against the president was kind of on weak legal ground and Mueller shouldn't have stacked his team with Democrats. It didn't look good. And he said, and I think this caught President Trump's attention, is that there's a lot of reasons to go after Hillary, on Uranium One and things like that, more than to go after Trump-Russia collusion in 2016.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not Uranium One again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hey, I didn't bring it up. That was Bob Barr.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- but, speaking of President Trump meeting with Bill Barr, he was asked about that. Let's play that sound and we will get Juan to react.

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.utterance: The president wanted to know yes, oh, you know Bob Mueller. How well do you know Bob Mueller? And I told him how well I knew Bob Mueller and I said Bob is a straight shooter and should be dealt with as such. And he said something to the effect like so, are you envisioning some role here? And I said, you know, actually, Mr. President, right now I couldn't do it. My personal and my professional obligations are such that I'm unable to do it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And Juan, in another exchange, Mr. Barr said that he does not believe Bob Mueller would ever be involved in a witch hunt. So, do you think Democrats will be satisfied with his hearing today?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: No. You know, to me, this is about Trump wants to control the Justice Department. I think that's why he forced out Jeff Sessions, who was a Trump loyalist but had recused himself. So I think the standards, Dana, for the Democrats was if the ethics officials come to you and say Mr. Attorney General, we think you should recuse yourself. Will you abide by their findings? And he said no. He said he would go with his own sense of whether or not he should be recused. Similarly and I think this is the big point, it's not a matter of, you know, the hate anybody club. There was a question about whether or not he will release the report, the Mueller report. And he said, you know what, the way that we deal with I think what they are called, declination memos, where they decline to prosecute somebody, is we don't go out and talk about them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And so we may not release all of it. Well, guess what, the polls are pretty clear on this. It's like a majority of Americans say his number one job should be release whatever Mueller finds. Don't cover it up. Don't let Giuliani edit it. Put it out there for the American people and he refuses to say that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And there have been Republican senators, Katie, who have said that they'd also want that report to be public, but it will be the attorney general's decision.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, it's been such a big topic of conversation for the country for the last two years, that it should be released in full as much as possible, but he didn't say he wasn't releasing it for reasons of personal or political purposes or because the president doesn't necessarily want it released. He specifically referred back to the rules and regulations that are in the Justice Department when it comes to releasing reports like this. But one thing I caught today that I found interesting is I think there was a bit of a missed opportunity because everything was so focused on Russia that all of these other issues kind of got ignored. For example, there were questions today about Bill Barr's role as attorney general in the 1990s when there was a lot of crime. There is a reason why violent crime and murder in America today has been cut in half. It's a result of a lot of the policies that they put into place. And as you have Cory Booker and Kamala Harris and President Trump pushing forward with criminal justice reform, which is important, he really did a good job of saying, look, I'm not going to apologize for the things that we did in the 1990s to bring down the crime across cities in America. At the same time, I am open to the idea that maybe we can pull some -- pull back on some of those policies now that we have solved a lot of the problem in places like New York and Washington, D.C. Chicago came up as one place where it hasn't been solved. So, that's an issue that will be ongoing for the next 10 to 20 years and I don't think that they really focused on it enough.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He also said, Greg that he would not target marijuana, like not the laws and they mess with what the states are trying to do. That's a good thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I guess it's a good thing. Well, and I think that was the other problem with Sessions, was that I think that he wasn't going to go for it. I think that's the direction of the country. And I do agree that we have to be really careful about talking about how great this police reform thing is going to be because the facts are the facts. We saw dramatic reduction in crime, and that had something to do with policies that we are now kind of saying, well maybe we don't need them anymore. And that's the thing that always happens. After something works, we all started thinking maybe we don't need it anymore like walls. We don't need any walls anymore.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Like the windows theory --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But he was very strong on border security. He said he supported barriers where they were necessary and he was also very against sanctuary cities. So I thought everybody watching should be pretty pleased with this guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, one thing I would say on this, from the Democrat's perspective, he is not Matt Whitaker.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, you know what --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe that was the strategy all along.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think so.

utterances.speaker: PEPRINO
utterances.utterance: All right, a new caravan with 2,000 migrants now heading for our southern border. The latest on the president battle for border security, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It is now day 25 of the partial government shutdown over border wall funding, the president pointing to a new migrant caravan on its way from Honduras heading toward the USA. Meanwhile, a new push from the president for border security -- he tweeted the following, "A drone flying around will not stop them. Only a wall will work." Also, Democrats declining Trump's invitation to the White House today, a small group. He wanted a working lunch with Democrats and Republicans to try to solve the crisis. While neither side is budging, the Senate has now created though a gang of 20 people -- 10 Republicans, 10 Democrats who are intent on trying to resolve the issue. So Jesse, today I was thinking to myself, we've seen the president talk about this new caravan. We've also seen him talk about yesterday the Hispanic caucus retreat in Puerto Rico. And then you had him sharing an article by an anonymous senior administration official saying these government workers are not loyal. They are not good people. I mean, he is on a campaign, but the polls don't seem to move.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think he's winning the argument on the logic of the wall and that's pretty clear, that walls work. You had Obama's chief Border Patrol agent say that walls work. Jim Acosta accidentally prove that walls work. So, the country gets that. But the problem is that he took ownership of the shut down a month ago. And the Democrats are just going to wait him out because they believe that they have the politics on their side. On the caravan, I talked to our chief caravan correspondence Griff Jenkins today. He said it's about 1,000 or 2,000 strong. And by Friday or Saturday, it's going to head to the border with Guatemala and Mexico where we saw all that violence last time where they tried to come over. Interestingly, out of the El Chapo case in Brooklyn, we have found out that El Chapo bribed the president of Mexico $100 million, the last president of Mexico, the one that just left office. But think about how corrupt that is. He's taking money from El Chapo.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Not surprised.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And this is the kind of country you're dealing with on the southern border.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But we should be fair to the former president of Mexico. We don't know that that's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe it was a down payment for the wall. I don't know Juan. Who knows?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Katie, one of the realities of the caravan is this time, as last time, you end up with people approaching, as Jesse was saying, the Mexican border. Mexico granted people in the last caravan humanitarian visas. Most of them remained there. A whole bunch of them went back to Latin America, other countries. So, how do you view this new caravan? Is this an invasion or is this a publicity effort to try to row support for the wall by the president?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I don't think that the caravan is a publicity stunt by the president. I think that they're making this journey because they believe that Democrats are going to allow them to come in because they don't believe in walls and they don't believe in any kind of other structure to stop them from coming in. They are getting impatient and jumping the border wall, what we have of it, anyway, which by the way, people who come to this country legally are also inpatient but they do it and they take the time and it takes 5 to 10 years for it to happen. But if you listen to what DHS is saying, what the ICE agents and Border Patrol agents are saying. These caravans are violent. It's the kind of violence they haven't seen before. And the new incoming Mexican president is actually looking to put more barriers on the southern border with Mexico to stop this from happening.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's immoral, Katie. How dare they?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Totally immoral if you can't handle it. But that's, you know, they are going to keep coming until you stop them. There is no reason why not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, and Dana, let's talk for a second about the lunch today or the lunch that didn't happen. The president tried to invite some - - what he described or the White House described as moderate Democrats, because he wanted to try to get around Pelosi and the leadership. But it looked like Pelosi held those people in place. They didn't go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. So, groups are stronger when they stick together. And so far the Republicans are sticking together and the Democrats are sticking together. So we are at quite an impasse. I thought that maybe you would start to see some Democrats. Remember Cher last week? She tweeted the thing saying, "This isn't worth it. Just give him the $5 billion for the wall. Let these workers get back to work for the government." I thought that might like pick up some steam but so far, no dice. I do think though on this issue with the caravan, people are on the move all around the world. This is not just happening at our southern border. That is why you have these problems in Europe. I think they had the big Brexit issue today. People are leaving because their governments are failing. And there's a bigger conversation that needs to be happening. There is a $5 billion squabble. It's a little bit petty compared to what is really going on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that's a really important point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's an OK point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a great point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's not like make it a great point, OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, let's not do that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because her ego --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I have --

utterances.speaker: WILLAIMS
utterances.utterance: I wanted to raise the point with you about McConnell.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I have three great points. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll be the judge of that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't want to talk about McConnell.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- lots of great points, Greg. Let me -- so what happens is you get a situation where McConnell is blocking a vote on the House package to re-open the government. Meanwhile --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because the president won't sign it so why should he do that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what McConnell said

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is a great point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Thank you. WILLIAMS: But meanwhile, the president and the White House are saying they are going to bring back half of the IRS agents.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So it's like he's deciding which part of the government stay shut even as he decides and declares the government is -- a third of the government should be shut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I have lost interest in that part. I want to make three interesting points here. I'm going to defend the caravan, number one, because you can't blame them for like, say, trying to go into California when you start offering them incentives like saying, hey, the taxpayers are going to pay for your insurance for illegal immigrants until you are 26. And if anyone happens to be a criminal, don't worry about it. We have ample sanctuary cities ready for you so, we are putting our citizens at risk. Hopefully, that if the people who get here survive, they'll vote Democrat. So I see the incentives as a huge problem. Number two, I'm wondering what the media is going to do about this incoming caravan because the initial caravan, remember, they called that a humanitarian crisis. And then when President Trump jumped in and said it was a humanitarian crisis, they said no, it wasn't. It wasn't at all. They mocked it. Now, you have a humanitarian crisis. There are kids coming. Kids could be hurt. Kids could die. Are they going to make fun of that or are they going to call it a crisis? Anyway, I also want to defend Mexico. We talked about the drugs coming in. I think we also need to face the facts of the demand.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like, it's not just about Mexico. It's about the demand, our demand. As long as we keep wanting this stuff, they are going to keep bringing it. And the interesting thing is, because we started growing our own marijuana here, that's hurt Mexican's business which is why they are not doing opiates. So, legalize the stuff, it will go away.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You ain't blowing smoke, brother.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I will later.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The president hosting the Clemson football team last night. He fed the players fast food. Why his critics are calling it a major fail McFail. (Inaudible)

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Trump hosted the college football national champion Clemson Tigers last night, but due to the shutdown, food options at the White House were limited. So, Trump ordered and personally paid for a massive spread of fast food.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Do we have no food for you, because we have a shut down or do we give you some little quick salads that the First Lady will make along with the Second Lady. They will make some salads. And I said you guys aren't into salads. We have Big Macs, we have quarter pounders with cheese we have everything I like that you like.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No good deed goes unpunished and it didn't take long for the Trump haters to start criticizing the event, starting with calling Trump sexist.

utterances.speaker: JOAN WALSH, THE NATION CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: That's appalling. It seemed to me like the president will not be happy until there's not one single female Republican voter in the country. It's incredibly sexist. We aren't all here to make salads for men.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: This is one of those things were sometimes what people say when they are being funny exposes exactly who they are and what they think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Then there is former NFL running back Reggie Bush. He took to twitter to vent his frustration saying the Clemson players deserve better, and that the meal was a huge slap in the face. And of course the late-night hosts didn't want to miss an opportunity to take their own shots at Trump.

utterances.speaker: SETH MEYERS, LATE NIGHT HOST
utterances.utterance: Do you think he's being so sly, normally I would have a salad for dinner on Monday but they told me they only eat every fast food.

utterances.speaker: JIMMY KIMMELL, LATE NIGHT SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: He's paying the check so he had to get the cheapest food they could find.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN COLBERT, LATE NIGHT SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: Is it possible you are just projecting your favorite foods onto them? We are going to eat all of their favorite foods, burgers, KFC, taco bowls, two scoops of ice cream. We are going to watch their favorite movie, the 2016 election results.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's my favorite movie too. Greg, people in the media don't like this, but all the Clemson players loved it. They went back for seconds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, this is fantastic. The idea that they believe that saying a woman makes a salad is sexist, that again -- the assumption is in Joan Walsh's head and then she projects it to other people like she hears salad, she goes sexist, that's appalling. What a bunch of losers. I mean, these are people that have become the Dean Wormer's of the world. They can't handle any fun, and Trump knows that. He knows the best revenge is to rub the fun in people's faces. And what Trump did was he re-created the dream every young man has. Imagine you have to go to some formal event and you are sitting on a bus and you are going like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't know what fork to use.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, and they are going like, what are they going to serve? I always know this, after we go to a formal dinner or whatever, we are going to In-n-Out burger or we're going to Jack-in-the-Box.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because you are still hungry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We are still hungry. But in this case, Trump knew that. They showed up. They actually took food home. They put food in their pockets. That was great. He's awesome. I love it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, have some nuggets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, because I got a colonoscopy tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, that was too much information.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't eat any food. I've been drinking bullion all day.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Katie, have a quarter pounder. Tell me what you think about this fast food.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think it's awesome. These guys are college students. Free food for anybody in college should be something amazing. What do they expect? They don't want some dried out chicken and asparagus they serve at all of these fancy events.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. You don't need silverware for a Big Mac.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And they are making fun of Trump for serving food he likes. He actually said that yesterday. He said, I like the American food. You like the best American food. We are all going to have great food. We're not going to let you go hungry. I think it's awesome. And my favorite part was the French Fries in the presidential seal cups.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Class all the way.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It was very classy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, what do you think here? If Obama did this, they'd love it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Look, everybody likes burgers. That's the only big thing about that. It's that you guys are so wrong. I mean, actually, if you go to an event at the White House and eat the food, the food is usually spectacular. I mean, it's like unbelievable. And even --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Is it as good as McDonald's, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- the cookies are great. No, you know, to me, this was Willy Wonka at the chocolate factory. Right? And he's got exactly what he wants, which is fast food. It's not about them. It's about him, which is for the narcissist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, why isn't it about the players, Juan?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: McDonald's is the product of narcissism.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why isn't it about the players?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you what. If he was about the players, I think he would've --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Taken orders.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- forked over a few more bucks and given them something memorable to eat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is memorable. It's all over television, all over their Instagram pics.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: As a joke.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, you can't have any fries.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't want -- I don't mind.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No fries. I'm going to take the fish filet, too, away from you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Those French fries are great, but did you see --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are great.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Did you see that, I think it's Burger King, said that he can't even spell. They're out of "hamberders" or whatever he typed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They got him on that one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So negative, Williams.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Another clear victory.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why are they attacking middle America?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Middle America?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Like, America loves fast food, and they're acting like it's the worst thing ever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I didn't say it was the worst thing ever. I just don't think -- and I think Reggie Bush said this.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You know, maybe Reggie Bush can pay for it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, he could have actually served them some good food at the White House.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Another -- another Bushie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think a Whopper is good food -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So I -- here's the thing. One of the best things that President Trump gave them last night is a story that they will tell for the rest of their lives.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Everybody will go, "Tell me about that time. Dad, tell us again about that time you went to the White House, and the president served you McDonald's." And it's going to be, like -- that's honestly one of the best things you could have given.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You got the buttermilk chicken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They had the McDonald's, and they had Wendy's, and they had Burger King.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, I would have served salads.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You would have served salads?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm having clear JELL-O tonight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It wouldn't have been eaten at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, that's right. But they also got -- I think it was Domino's pizza.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And pizza. And pizza. I was surprised there was no Chick-Fil-A. But next time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you wanted to politicize it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe when they three-peat.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, they have the best chicken nuggets on the planet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The left didn't do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The best nuggets on the planets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's sexist, you eating that sandwich.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Want me to tease that for you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why don't you tease while I eat?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Gillette facing razor-sharp criticism over its new ad challenging men to shave off their toxic masculinity. That's next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Gillette, a company supported by men for over a century, debuted a new ad crapping all over the very same men. The video featured sinister males bullying and sexually harassing: what Gillette calls toxic masculinity. Yes, toxic masculinity, the term of endearment embraced by dismal teachers lounges everywhere to smear an entire gender. Apparently, Gillette execs must've been reading Teen Vogue.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Bullying.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The #MeToo movement against sexual harassment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Toxic masculinity.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Is this the best a man can get? Is it?

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Freak!

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: You're such a loser.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We can't hide from it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Sexual harassment is taking over --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's been going on far too long. We can't laugh it off --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Who's the Daddy?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: What I actually think she's trying to say --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: -- making the same old excuses.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Boys will be boys.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Boys will be boys.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Boys will be boys.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Boys will be boys.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Boys will be boys.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Something finally changed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Allegations regarding sexual assault and sexual harassment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Toxic masculinity.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: And there will be no going back. Because we, we believe in the best in men.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's almost as if the people who make products for men hate men. So what is Gillette really trying to sell? Is it razors or itself? As the company loses market share to Dollar Shave Club, Gillette makes an ad that shafts the company's key audience, just to score a few virtue points with the social justice mob. They say they're sparking conversation, but that's what they call it when they tie you to a chair and shout accusations at you, then asking for money. But how enlightened is Gillette, really? Look at these razors. The blue is for males, and the pink is for females. Talk about enforcing gender stereotypes. Now, the cowardly media, scared of the social media mob, backs the ad. Meanwhile, everybody else hates it. And Gillette will say it's because the ad spotlights bad male behavior, and we insecure rubes, we just can't handle it. No, it's because the ad sucks.

utterances.speaker: Gillette didn't just condemn bad behavior, something most men do whenever they see it
utterances.utterance: it suggested that behavior represents the norm. It sold you out and judged you. Gillette said, you know, our consumers are beastly, and you should applaud us for being brave enough to say so. Sorry if we don't. We're too busy joining Dollar Shave Club. All right, Dana. That was pretty -- it was -- did you know they were selling razors? What were they selling?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, I think that you're right. They're trying -- they're try -- they really wanted us to talk about them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that you're right. So like, the more -- and I was wondering about --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Which is cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember when Nike did the ad for Colin Kaepernick

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it was like "What are they doing?" and then their market share went way up?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And they sold more shoes and products. And all around the world. So perhaps younger men are going to like this ad. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, they are not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can guarantee you --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I hope not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- no man likes that ad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I also -- I feel like, well, there needs to be more men in the lives of boys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's a good point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That would be a good ad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So there needs -- like men need to step up to the children that they father.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They need to stick around, and they need to be there for their children. Like, this to me is actually a really important point. That would be a better ad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Jesse, they didn't address that -- that part.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They just -- they bashed men, men who fought wars, who build bridges. They just bashed them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I don't want to feel guilty about the behavior of a few bad apples.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I feel guilty enough over my own behavior. I don't need it to be pointed out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're one bad apple.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. So I also want a good shave. I don't want to have a conversation about anything. OK? The point of a razor, is they're talking about a brand. I want to know about a product. Because you don't wear a razor. A razor is all about performance. It's about how it glides. It's about you don't get any nicks and cuts. It's about how nice the handle feels or how sharp it is. That's what it's about. I want to see the razor go down a man's face, and I want to see the cream come off like that. That's how I know it's good. I don't even know -- like you said, what are they talking about? Who knows? This was like you said, they're trying to suck up to the Madison Avenue people, because they want to go viral; and they want everybody to be talking about how they're trending. But meanwhile, they're just making everybody feel guilty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, Katie, I think it's -- virtual signaling is now an insurance policy against social-media mobs. They just know that they've got to protect themselves, and they know that everybody in media and advertising is going to fall in line, because if they don't agree with it, then they could be persecuted.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And they pull the ads, right. Well, it's just stupid. Like, who are you trying to impress? Right? I mean, the entire ad is insulting to the very people who are their customers. And I am getting really sick and tired of men in this country being demonized because of the behavior of other men.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There are things that women do that are bad also, and if we want to talk about toxic masculinity, maybe we should talk about toxic femininity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It exists.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And toxic feminism. And the fact that taking men out of being masculine isn't going to make their behavior better. It's only going to take things that the country has built itself upon out of the picture and make the behavior worse. Men need men to show them how to be good people, to have morals and values. That doesn't mean they have to stop acting like men.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, there could have been a positive message, Juan. But in this case, it was negative. The assumption being that men don't have sisters, don't have mothers, don't have daughters, granddaughters. That we actually love women. In this case, we're just awful people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I really think you're off on this one. And I'm a guy, but when I must say that, when it comes to any talk about racism, the Steve Kings of the world; when it comes to misogyny; when it comes to bullying, you guys react like, "Oh, somebody is attacking the Republican Party." I'm like, "What?"

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Who said that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's B.S. That is pure B.S. That had nothing to do with racism or Steve King.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You -- you -- you know what? You know what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are so wrong. Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And by the way --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, that is so pathetic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you are --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you are out -- totally out of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're embarrassing yourself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- keeping with a company that's here to make money, just like we talked about Nike.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I agree. Just make money. Just to make money.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Please, just give me a second. So what you have here is a company that I don't doubt tested this and found that men, in fact, are moving away from "all men have to be stoic."

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Then we're doomed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: "All men have to project" --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: America is over.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- "that they are extremely confident."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Stoicism is growing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? You have a situation here where high rates of violence, high rates of depression, high rates of spousal abuse, men.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why is that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Men understand that there is a change taking place. And I think it's also the case that, as we see shifts in demographics about Hispanic men, black men, Asian men, that there's more and more open to the idea that, you know, it's a different definition of what it means to be "big daddy" in this country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That made -- that made no sense at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Gillette is at the cutting edge of saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Cutting edge, good one, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- hey, there's a movement. Yes, I agree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That made no sense. OK. How has "The Five" aged in the past ten years? We'll show you as we join the latest social media trend, next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: A new viral challenge has hit social media. It's called the ten- year challenge, where users post side-by-side photos of themselves from 2009 and 2019 to show how much they've aged. Here are a few celebrity examples. There's actress Reese Witherspoon. Television host and radio star Ryan Seacrest. And actor and comedian Kevin hard. And now "The Five" is joining in on the fun. I wanted to do this --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Celebrities.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- with my Instagram pictures, so I'm really glad that we're doing this. Juan, show us the past ten years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, there you go. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Explain the context of these photos.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think the -- I think the big difference there would be the hair. I think my hairline is a little weaker now. And I think that I have more gray before I started putting some color in there. But I think the other thing -- the other thing that strikes me about this is the question of wrinkles. And it doesn't look like I've done too badly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, you're pretty good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like the gray better.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pretty good on that front.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'd get rid of that jacket, though.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You like -- you don't like the brown jacket?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like the gray.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It was ten years ago, bro. Ten years.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It was in style then. OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think it was.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know what this picture looks like, but let's roll it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I remember that. That's in Ventura Beach, California, I think. Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Was that a "Watters' World" assignment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a "Watters' World," yes, of course. Wow. I think I -- that hair was not good back then.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have good hair now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think my hair is better now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ten years from now, you'll feel differently.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It looks like someone's goosing you in that current picture.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It does. Looks like it. OK, Greg. Your turn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ooh, jeez.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oooh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow. I look -- my teeth are darker. Could that be the wine?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's just the light. I think it's the lighting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it's the wine. Definitely losing some hair. That's for sure. And it seems that I've gotten shorter, which technically, I think every decade -- every decade, you do get shorter.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's only shorter because your hair looks shorter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My teeth. I've got to get my teeth whitened. Jeez Louise.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana has a dentist for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I -- yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whoa, that's a different picture.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That is, like, a totally different -- I was like -- ten years ago I could barely walk by the end of -- that was my last press briefing, which was about a year ago this week --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you sure that's you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Ten years ago this week.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's Dana at the White House in the Brady Briefing Room.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have some time now to do some hair and makeup.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Aww.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK, here's mine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did not have hair and makeup.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Here I am on the left at my college news station, doing the weekly political statement. And there I am on "The Five" yesterday. So I think that I've improved quite a bit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Jeez, wow.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I would say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a little humbling, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Look, I'm in a T-shirt like Steve Hilton on the left. My hair is green from the green screen. We didn't have much editing going on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Weren't you playing sports at that time?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Not in college. In high school, but not in college. So I feel like I've come a long way. Ten years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That was pretty fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't like mine. I think the producers are mad at me for some reason.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It was a pretty good picture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not a good picture, guys. Let's work on that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You went on TV that way. You went on TV that way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I didn't have hair and makeup. I was the only one with no hair and makeup.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You could have sent in your own photos.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't have pictures of myself from ten years ago. What am I, a narcissist?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Some of us decided to -- did you see my hair? My hair was green. At least your hair wasn't green.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It looked like you at least tried to do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did not try.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: At least you looked like the same person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It was windswept.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You do look like the same person.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a look, wasn't it? The little bob?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This difference doesn't matter until you're way older, like between 70 and 80. Then the difference really tells.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Or like a 20-year difference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But what would your advice be, Greg, to those who are getting older?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It gets better.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Are you sure?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Way better. Trust me. Oh, man. It's so much more fun. You stop caring, you do whatever you want.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you become an angry old coot. That's it. I've got to tell you, so this year, 2019, I'm going to be 65. And so I'm thinking, boy, this -- is there going to be, like, an immediate drop off?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you going to retire, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Only -- only if you come with me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I want that -- I want that hairstyle.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right, well, Juan is not retiring, just so everybody knows. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Time for --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Journey to a Driver's License!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Journey to a Driver's License!" Yes, I'm going to take you along this journey, America. So I went to the DMV, and I got a 20 out of 20 on my written exam.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I did drop my Social Security card on the floor, and I was in an ensuing panic, running around screaming and yelling. Having said that, and I thought everything was great. And then I was told as I was leaving, that, "And you will have to sign up for a five-hour" -- I have to sign up for a five-hour driver's course.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I have to take a driver's course. So if there's anybody in New York who does a drivers course, give me a call. Because I'm going to - - I don't even know how to do it! I don't know, where am I going to go?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What does that mean? Like a racecar course?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They have schools. I don't want to go to a school. There's got to be some kind of independent dude with a pickup truck.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why are you getting a driver's license, by the way?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because I -- I've got to start driving again.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's been a long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wants some independence.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I need some independence.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you've got to have an escape from the city.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Going to take five hours to get there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I went to the DMV this morning, and I'm getting a colonoscopy tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is a banner week for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what the best part about you going to the DMV? You didn't do "Animals Are Great" tonight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very good. All right. I'm going to go next. A new study gives me so much hope. It's about Americans' reading habits. Jesse, pay attention.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The study found that 86 percent of those surveyed feel they make a conscious effort to read in some way every day. And get this: The biggest number, between 25- and 34-year-olds. They read almost three hours a day. So this is, like, a really good thing. Right? People thought that books were going to go away, people aren't going to read anymore. But they are, and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What are they reading?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm going to tell you what I've read recently. Three books I've read recently.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, what are they saying they're reading? They're reading on the Internet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Social media, but they're also reading proper books.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not reading.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Proper books. Finishing a book. I mean, 67 percent of respondents say they feel accomplished after reading a book. So maybe they're buying your books. Let's be celebratory. Those are some books I've read. "Bridge of Clay" by Markus Zusak. I loved it. "My Absolute Darling," oh, my gosh. That one was really hard. And "Stories I Tell My Friends" by Rob Lowe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "Art of the Deal" was pretty good. Read that one?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Everybody has. Everybody has read that book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Page turner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, wait. It's Juan's turn.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So you know, the little kid in me loves to watch things go boom. And so take a look at what happened to New York's Tappan Zee Bridge today.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow. Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, the eastern section of the bridge tumbled into the Hudson River. Once the waves of black smoke dispersed in the cold winter air, the bridge could be seen half-submerged in the chilly waters. Hundreds of New Yorkers braved the cold to witness the 63-year-old bridge's demolition. They chanted, "Blow it up! Blow it up!" The bridge is being replaced by a new bridge named for Mario Cuomo, the father of New York's current governor. So --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who built that bridge, Juan!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What did you say?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who built that bridge, do you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe some men did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Watching this blow up, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, women can't build bridges. That's impossible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, go next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't drive over that bridge, by the way. It's blown up. You're going to get hurt. All right. The Jets brought in the head coach for Miami. This guy, Gase, he had a press conference. Look at this guy. This is -- this is the new head coach of your New York Jets, everybody.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Did he do this on purpose? Did he do this on purpose? Come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know we've got some Jets fans here in the building. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like, what is he doing, seriously?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This will be -- this guy will be leading your team into the playoffs. I'm just kidding.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Was this on purpose so he never has to do another press conference?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one knows. No one knows why he's doing this or what he's doing. But that's the head coach of the Jets.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: "Maybe if I do this, they'll never come after me (PH)."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, "Watters' World" has its own Instagram page now. So there you go. Go leave me all your nasty comments in one place, and I'll read them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Katie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
